occurrences.line_text: The greatest portion of the greedie pray;
Such was the conflict of those cruell Brigants there.
Least they should ioyne against the weaker side,
Or rise against the remnant at their will;
Was by the Captaine all this while defended:
He at the length was slaine, and layd on ground,
Fayre Pastorell, who with the selfe same wound
Lanc't through the arme, fell down with him in drerie swound.
Tho when as he was dead, the fray gan ceasse,
Sith they that were the cause of all, were gone.
And in his armes the dreary dying mayd,
Yet did the cloud make euen that dimmed light
And twixt the twinckling of her eye-lids bright,
But when they mou'd the carcases aside,
To call the soule backe to her home againe;
They left her so, in charge of one the best
Who when he backe returned from the wood,
That more increast the anguish of his paine.
He sought the woods; but no man could see there;
He sought the plaines; but could no tydings heare.
The woods did nought but ecchoes vaine rebound;
The playnes all waste and emptie did appeare:
Where wont the shepheards oft their pypes resound,
That Coridon it was, the silly shepherds hynd.
To greet him first, but askt were where the rest;
Whereat the knight amaz'd, yet did not rest,
Where was his Pastorell? where all the other crew?
How could the death dare euer her to quell?
Tho when the shepheard breathed had awhile,
First all the captiues, which they here had hent,
But when the lot to Pastorell did fall,
Oft cursing th'heauens, that so cruell were
The readie way vnto that theeuish wonne,
Vnto the place, to see what should be donne.
But by all meanes the daunger knowne did shonne:
Tho to the place when they approched nye,
The selfe same flocks, the which those theeues had reft
The selfe same flocks, the which those theeues had reft
And certaine of the theeues there by them left,
The which for want of heards themselues then kept.
But when he saw the theeues, which did them keepe,
Him hardly forward drew, whereas the thiefe
Lay sleeping soundly in the bushes shade,
Now all vnwares, and take the spoyle away;
But gently waking them, gaue them the time of day.
Tho sitting downe by them vpon the greene,
Mongst which the theeues them questioned againe,
That they were poore heardgroomes, the which whylere
But to forray the land, or scoure the deepe.
But to forray the land, or scoure the deepe.
So there all day they bode, till light the sky forsooke.
And all the secrets of their entrayles sought.
That Pastorell yet liu'd, but all the rest
In dead of night, when all the theeues did rest
With which he streight went to the Captaines nest.
When to the Caue they came, they found it fast:
The dores assayled, and the locks vpbrast.
The dores assayled, and the locks vpbrast.
With noyse whereof the theefe awaking light,
Vnto the entrance ran: where the bold knight
Vnto the entrance ran: where the bold knight
The whiles faire Pastorell through great affright
At length espyes at hand the happie cost,
The hue and cry was raysed all about;
And all the Brigants flocking in great store,
Vnto the caue gan preasse, nought hauing dout
But Calidore in th'entry close did stand,
Still slew the formost, that came first to hand,
So long till all the entry was with bodies mand.
He breath'd his sword, and rested him till day:
Which when he spyde vpon the earth t'encroch,
Through the dead carcases he made his way;
With which he forth went into th'open light:
Where all the rest for him did readie stay,
That all the place with swarmes do ouerlay,
Till he had strowd with bodies all the way;
And forth her bringing to the ioyous light,
Whereof she long had lackt the wishfull sight,
The sad remembrance of her wretched plight.
And thence did all the spoyles and threasures take,
But fortune now the victors meed did make;
Of which the best he did his loue betake;
Calidore doth the Blatant beast
Like as a ship, that through the Ocean wyde
To shew the courtesie by him profest,
Euen vnto the lowest and the least.
Euen vnto the lowest and the least.
To his atchieuement of the Blatant beast;
Vnto the Castle of Belgard her brought,
Whereof was Lord the good Sir Bellamoure;
The fayrest Ladie then of all that liuing were.
The Lord of Many Ilands, farre renound
He through the wealth, wherein he did abound,
Vnto the Prince of Picteland bordering nere,
That neither could to company of th'other creepe.
The trustie damzell bearing it abrode
Into the emptie fields, where liuing wight
Mote not bewray the secret of her lode,
She forth gan lay vnto the open light
The litle babe, to take thereof a sight.
Vpon the litle brest like christall bright,
Well she it markt, and pittied the more,
Bedeaw'd with teares there left it in the place:
Behind the bushes, where she her did hyde,
Would for the wretched infants helpe prouyde,
His fleecie flocke vpon the playnes around,
Led with the infants cry, that loud did weepe,
Came to the place, where when he wrapped found
Th'abandond spoyle, he softly it vnbound;
Then all the stormes of fortunes former yre
No lesse did tender the faire Pastorell,
Vntill the damzell gan to wex more sound and strong.
The which the Faery Queene had long afore
The which the Faery Queene had long afore
Bequeath'd to him, forslacked had so sore;
Besides the losse of so much loos and fame,
As through the world thereby should glorifie his name.
Throughout the world, and to destruction brought.
Whom to recomfort, all the meanes he wrought,
What did betide to the faire Pastorell,
The rosie marke, which she remembred well
The daughter of her Lady Claribell,
The which she bore, the whiles in prison she did dwell.
The which she bore, the whiles in prison she did dwell.
She in the open fields had loosely layd
To tell her, how the heauens had her graste,
The sober mother seeing such her mood,
And what the matter was, that mou'd her so.
A little mayde, the which ye chylded tho;
The same againe if now ye list to haue,
The same is yonder Lady, whom high God did saue.
Much was the Lady troubled at that speach,
The litle purple rose, which thereon grew,
The matrone stayd no lenger to enquire,
But forth in hast ran to the straunger Mayd;
Who euer is the mother of one chylde,
Him follow'd, by the tract of his outragious spoile.
And to the Clergy now was come at last;
That endlesse were to tell. The Elfin Knight,
Through which the Monckes he chaced here & there.
Nought sparing them, the more did tosse and teare,
From thence into the sacred Church he broke,
And robd the Chancell, and the deskes downe threw,
And robd the Chancell, and the deskes downe threw,
And th'Images for all their goodly hew,
A full good pecke within the vtmost brim,
Appearing like the mouth of Orcus griesly grim.
The tongues of Serpents with three forked stings,
That th'outrage of his violence he stayd,
And spitting forth the poyson of his spight,
Full cruelly the Beast did rage and rore,
For still the more he stroue, the more the Knight
For still the more he stroue, the more the Knight
For still the more he stroue, the more the Knight
Or like the hell-borne Hydra, which they faine
To crop his thousand heads, the which still new
Such was the fury of this hellish Beast,
But aye the more he rag'd, the more his powre increast.
But aye the more he rag'd, the more his powre increast.
Tho when the Beast saw, he mote nought auaile,
Brought forth with him the dreadfull dog of hell,
To see the hatefull sunne, that he might tell
And to the other damned ghosts, which dwell
Yet greatly did the Beast repine at those
The proued powre of noble Calidore,
And like a fearefull dog him followed through the land.
That all the people where so he did go,
And seeing it, much wondred at the sight;
And much admyr'd the Beast, but more admyr'd the Knight.
And much admyr'd the Beast, but more admyr'd the Knight.
Thus was this Monster by the maystring might
And got into the world at liberty againe.
The good Sir Pelleas him tooke in hand,
So now he raungeth through the world againe,
Ne spareth he the gentle Poets rime,
But he would not endure that wofull theame
The pointed steele arriuing rudely theare,
And goodly gorgeous barbes, him found not theare.
Doth not so much reioyce, as she reioyced theare.
And fals to ground, to seeke for succour theare,
Now freely drew, and found right safe assurance theare.
At puffe of euery storme doth stagger here and theare.
So as they courst, and turneyd here and theare,
That seem'd like siluer, sprinckled here and theare
Should with the rest be sold before him theare,
Such as the troubled Theaters oftimes annoyes.
And did like an halfe Theatre fulfill:
And like a stately Theatre it made,
Of some Theatre, a graue personage,
Vnto that Monster, whom the Theban Knight,
Then shewd it, how the Thebane Semelee
In Thebes, which Alexander did confound;
Of fatall Thebes, of Rome that raigned long,
Strangle her, else she sure will strangle thee.
He bids thee to him send for his intent
Had not that charme from thee forwarned it:
But yet I warne thee now assured sitt,
Nor guilefull sprite, to thee these wordes doth speake,
Life from Sansfoy thou tookst, Sansloy shall fro[m] thee take.
That hath thee hither brought to taste mine yre?
Alone he wandring thee too long doth want:
And gorgeous gold arayd I to thee came;
And how haue seene vnwares. Lo now I go with thee.
From hope of heauen hath thee excluded quight,
And fearest not, that more thee hurten might,
In medicine, that else hath to thee wonne
Thy guilty wrong, or else thee guilty yield.
In euill houre thy foes thee hither sent,
Hath thee incenst, to hast thy dolefull fate?
Aread in grauer wise, what I demaund of thee.
What iustice can but iudge against thee right,
Thee, foolish man, so rash a doome to giue?
Against the day of wrath, to burden thee?
What grace hath thee now hither brought this way?
By wise Fidelia? she doth thee require,
Then seeke this path, that I to thee presage,
Which after all to heauen shall thee send;
Where is for thee ordaind a blessed end:
Sith to thee is vnknowne the cradle of thy brood.
From thence a Faerie thee vnweeting reft,
And her base Elfin brood there for thee left.
Thence she thee brought into this Faerie lond,
And in an heaped furrow did thee hyde,
Where thee a Ploughman all vnweeting fond,
And brought thee vp in ploughmans state to byde,
Whereof Georgos he thee gaue to name;
And proue thy puissaunt armes, as seemes thee best became.
The many fauours I with thee haue found,
Therefore since now to thee perteines the same,
Both daughter and eke kingdome, lo I yield to thee.
To thee, most mighty king of Eden faire,
And bids thee be aduized for the best,
So bids thee well to fare, Thy neither friend, nor foe, Fidessa.
To tell this ruefull tale; thy sight could win thee grace.
God guide thee, Guyon, well to end thy warke,
Well mote yee thee, as well can wish your thought,
Sith heauen thee deignes to hold in liuing state,
Hard helpe at need. So deare thee babe I bought,
Left thee for portion of thy liuelihed,
Great fauour I thee graunt, for aunswere thus to stay.
I giue thee life: therefore prostrated fall,
Seemes that through many yeares thy wits thee faile,
And that weake eld hath left thee nothing wise,
O Goddesse, (for such I thee take to bee)
Nor voyce sound mortall; I auow to thee,
To weet, which of the Gods I shall thee name,
That vnto thee due worship I may rightly frame.
All haile, Sir knight, and well may thee befall,
The wood is fit for beasts, the court is fit for thee.
What great despight doth fortune to thee beare,
But if she had her least helpe to thee lent,
Though she thy Lady be, approch thee neare;
Least worse betide thee by some later chaunce.
For feare of further harme, I counsell thee,
Great cause, that carries thee so swift and light.
But litle may such guile thee now auaile,
To him that giues thee life and libertie,
Which thee to endlesse bale captiued lead.
That thee against me drew with so impetuous dread.
That ill beseemes thee, such as I thee see,
That ill beseemes thee, such as I thee see,
To worke such shame. Therefore I thee exhort,
(Said he) that thee so sore displeased hath?
Whose freedome shall thee turne to greatest scath.
Loe there they be; to thee I yield them free.
Bid thee to them thy fruitlesse labours yield,
The shame and death, which will thee soone inuade?
What coward hand shall doe thee next to die,
Pyrrochles, Ã´ Pyrrochles, what is thee betyde?
What hellish furie hath at earst thee hent?
Furious euer I thee knew to bee,
What flames (quoth he) when I thee present see,
I read thee rash, and heedlesse of thy selfe,
All these may not suffise, there shall to thee
Sheilds, steeds, and armes, & all things for thee meet
And crownes and kingdomes to thee multiply.
If then thee list my offred grace to vse,
If thee list not, leaue haue thou to refuse:
Such grace now to be happy, is before thee laid.
Eternall God thee saue from such decay.
Proceeded, lo now is reueald to thee.
Auise thee well, and chaunge thy wilfull mood,
That she may thee aduance for workes and merites iust.
But if that thou be such, as I thee see,
Of grace I pray thee, giue to eat and drinke to mee.
Of his deare safetie, I to thee commend;
The same to thee, against his lord to fight,
That twise hath sped; yet shall it not thee keepe
Life will I graunt thee for thy valiaunce,
Haue made thee souldier of that Princesse bright,
Which now thou bear'st, to thee descended farre
Faire mote he thee, the prowest and most gent,
Yet thee fierce Fortune did so nearely driue,
That had not grace thee blest, thou shouldest not suruiue.
But Palmer, if it mote thee so aggrate,
Let not thee grieue dismounted to haue beene,
That speare enchaunted was, which layd thee on the greene.
But weenedst thou what wight thee ouerthrew,
Hath thee opprest, and with sad drearyhead
Chaunged thy liuely cheare, and liuing made thee dead?
Then doth this wicked euill thee infest,
Ah Nurse, what needeth thee to eke my paine?
And thee abandond wholly doe possesse,
Against it strongly striue, and yield thee not,
Then I auow to thee, by wrong or right
Well did Antiquitie a God thee deeme,
To order them, as best to thee doth seeme,
For fear the cruell Feends should thee vnwares deuowre.
Then Glauce thus, Let not it thee offend,
Certes I should be loth thee to molest:
The which the powres to thee are pleased to reuele.
Hast learn'd to loue, let no whit thee dismay
The hard begin, that meets thee in the dore,
Thy fruitfull Ofspring, shall from thee descend;
Till thy wombes burden thee from them do call,
And his last fate him from thee take away,
Where thee yet shall he leaue for memory
To thee shall represent. He from the head
Vnto thy selfe, and equall courage to thee take.
As thee, ï¿½ Queene, the matter of my song,
Great Neptune, I auow to hallow vnto thee.
I read thee soone retyre, whiles thou hast might,
Words fearen babes. I meane not thee entreat
To passe; but maugre thee will passe or dy.
Th'immortall name, with which thee yet vnborne
And they more fond, that credit to thee giue,
Nath'lesse to thee thy folly I forgiue,
What had th'eternall Maker need of thee,
Doth praise thee oft, and oft from Stygian deepe
Calles thee, his goddesse in his error blind,
For light ylike is loth'd of them and thee,
Speed thee to spred abroad thy beames bright?
To whom the Prince; Dwarfe, comfort to thee take,
I here auow thee neuer to forsake.
Now God thee keepe, thou gentlest Squire aliue,
Else shall thy louing Lord thee see no more,
Angell, or Goddesse do I call thee right?
What seruice may I do vnto thee meete,
The knight) inquire of thee, what were those three,
But if thee list to see thy Courser ronne,
It yrkes me, leaue thee in this wofull state,
That hast a thanklesse seruice on thee ta'ne,
Vpon thee heapt a direfull destinie,
And in their foolish fancie feigne thee blind,
Thou seest all, yet none at all sees thee;
Then now, that noble succour is thee by,
I tread in dust thee and thy money both,
Brought thee from balefull house of Proserpine,
Where in her bosome she thee long had nurst,
In which that boy thee plonged, for despight,
For thy, he thrild thee with a leaden dart,
To loue faire Daphne, which thee loued lesse:
Lesse she thee lou'd, then was thy iust desart,
Yet both in flowres do liue, and loue thee beare,
Be sure, that nought may saue thee from to dy,
Deawd with ambrosiall kisses, by thee gotten
Well falles it thee that I am not in plight
This day, to wreake the dammage by thee donne:
Why do I not it wreake, on thee now in my might?
And steale from thee the meede of thy due merit,
Lo faitour there thy meede vnto thee take,
Haue I thus long thy life vnto thee let:
This dismall day hath thee a caytiue made,
Or wrath of cruell wight on thee ywrake?
Or selfe disliked life doth thee thus wretched make?
Be theirs, that haue so cruell thee forlorne;
Thee goddesse, thee the winds, the clouds doe feare,
Thee goddesse, thee the winds, the clouds doe feare,
Then doth the dï¿½dale earth throw forth to thee
Chirpe loud to thee out of their leauy cages,
And thee their mother call to coole their kindly rages.
So all the world by thee at first was made,
Know Marinell that all this is for thee.
The liuing Lady, which from thee he reaued:
Encroch vppon the land there vnder thee;
Or shew the wounds, which vnto thee befell;
Goe streight, and take with thee, to witnesse it,
I trust a liue, sith I thee fostred first;
This griefes deepe wound I would to thee disclose,
And all thy forces gather vnto thee;
Defend thee from the vengeance of thy fone,
Of Guizor, by thee slaine, and murdred by thy slight.
They doe thy sire, lamenting sore for thee;
They doe to thee in this same dreame discouer.
To hinder thee from the iust heritage
So blesse thee God, and giue thee ioyance of thy dreame
So blesse thee God, and giue thee ioyance of thy dreame
Who then can thee, Mercilla, throughly prayse,
What guerdon can I giue thee for thy paine,
What new ocasion doth thee hither driue,
Vnhappy Squire, what hard mishap thee brought
And thee captyued in this shamefull place?
And turne thee soone to him, of whom thou art defyde.
And spoile my selfe, that can not thee withstand?
Will it auenge, and pay thee with thy right:
And if none do, yet shame shal thee with shame requight.
Who scornes thy ydle scoffe, and bids thee be defyde.
In blood of knight, the which by thee is slaine,
By thee no knight; which armes impugneth plaine?
Well may I certes such an one thee read,
But should it not displease thee it to tell;
I would thy selfe require thee to reueale,
And wish thee grow in worship and great weale.
Loe I defie thee, and here challenge make,
That euer I this life vnto thee lent,
For first it was to thee reprochfull blame,
The which hath doen to thee this wrongfull deed,
Vnto thy loue, that made thee low to lout;
Thy Loue is present there with thee in place,
Which to thee flocke, to heare thy louely layes;
Which here with thee doe make their pleasant playes?
Tell, me what were they all, whose lacke thee grieues so sore.
As he hath sung of thee in all his dayes,
Thus to bereaue thy Loues deare sight from thee:
Whom when that theefe approching nigh espide,
Him calling theefe, them whores; that much did vexe
With noyse whereof the theefe awaking light,
High heauen beholds sad louers nightly theeueryes.
Vow'd to the gods: religio[n] held euen theeues in measure.
Now made the spoile of theeues and Brigants bad,
And carried captiue by those theeues away;
Of griesly theeues, she thought her self in hell,
The theeues fall out for Pastorell,
Amongst those theeues, which her in bondage strong
By some of these same theeues at the instant brunt,
Therewith some other of the chiefest theeues
Or how those theeues, whilest one sought her to hold,
The selfe same flocks, the which those theeues had reft
And certaine of the theeues there by them left,
But when he saw the theeues, which did them keepe,
Mongst which the theeues them questioned againe,
Vnto their hellish dens those theeues them brought;
In dead of night, when all the theeues did rest
So many theeues about him swarming are,
But what befell her in that theeuish wonne,
The readie way vnto that theeuish wonne,
This doen, into those theeuish dens he went,
Such men do Chaungelings call, so chaungd by Faeries theft.
So hid in lockes and waues from lookers theft,
Light-shonning theft, and traiterous intent,
Made him seeme happie for so glorious theft;
For from that time I from enchaunters theft
Was fled to hell, surcharg'd with spoile and theft.
Of two full hard to read the harder theft.
Did neede to gard from force, or secret theft
For ayde, against that cruell Tyrants theft,
That piteous spoile by so iniurious theft.
And wretched life forlorne for vengement of his theft.
In which such spoile, such hauocke, and such theft
Their scepters stretcht from East to Westerne shore,
And all the world in their subiection held;
Forwasted all their land, and them expeld:
Seemd in their song to scorne the cruell sky.
That makes them doubt, their wits be not their owne:
That makes them doubt, their wits be not their owne:
Their dam vpstart, out of her den effraide,
Markes which do byte their hasty supper best;
All striuing to infixe their feeble stings,
That from their noyance he no where can rest,
But with his clownish hands their tender wings
He brusheth oft, and oft doth mar their murmurings.
Her scattred brood, soone as their Parent deare
Weening their wonted entrance to haue found
And sucked vp their dying mothers blood,
Making her death their life, and eke her hurt their good.
Making her death their life, and eke her hurt their good.
Deuoure their dam; on whom while so he gazd,
Hauing all satisfide their bloudy thurst,
Their bellies swolne he saw with fulnesse burst,
Rest is their feast, and all things at their will;
Rest is their feast, and all things at their will;
And the sad humour loading their eye liddes,
Vnto their lodgings then his guestes he riddes:
A-waite whereto their seruice he applyes,
Watching to banish Care their enimy,
Thus well instructed, to their worke they hast,
Came to their wicked maister, and gan tell
Their bootelesse paines, and ill succeeding night:
That daunted with their forces hideous,
Their steeds do stagger, and amazed stand,
Astonied with the stroke of their owne hand,
Their horned fronts so fierce on either side
The broken reliques of their former cruelty.
And through their iron sides with cruell spies
As from a forge out of their burning shields,
Till weary of their way, they came at last,
Their armes abroad, with gray mosse ouercast,
And their greene leaues trembling with euery blast,
From the fierce heat, and rest their weary limbs a tide.
When Witches wont do penance for their crime)
That in their cotage small, that night she rest her may.
Wont to robbe Churches of their ornaments,
And poore mens boxes of their due reliefe,
The holy Saints of their rich vestiments
And spoild the Priests of their habiliments,
And on their former iourney forward pas,
For anguish great they gan to rend their heare,
And beat their brests, and naked flesh to teare.
And when they both had wept and wayld their fill,
To follow her, that was the causer of their ill.
